creator: holtdl@yahoo.com
text:
$ ant -Dfoo
$ ant -verbose -Dfoo
Apache Ant version 1.5 compiled on July 9 2002
$ ant -Dfoo -verbose
Buildfile: build.xml

BUILD FAILED
file:c:/TEMP/build.xml:14: The 'file' property must be set.

Total time: 1 second

-------
Note that the first one doesn't output anything -- it just returns (it does 
exit 1, though, so that's at least good :)  The second one does basically what 
the first one does, in that it "mostly" just returns -- except the version gets 
printed, because that's the first thing -verbose does (it also at least exits 
1). The third one almost works right, except note that the output isn't in fact 
verbose.

I've always felt that we should map -Dsomething to -Dsomething=true; cos I have
regularly forgotten to say what I was defining something to and got odd messages
back,
creator: stevel@apache.org

text:
The third one sets the property foo to -verbose.

Ant accepts both -Dfoo=bar and -Dfoo bar as a way to set foo to bar.  I've been
told that is because Windows goes ahead and converts a=b into two arguments
a and b (stripping the equals sign completely) when invoking a batch file.
creator: bodewig@apache.org

text: The windows behaviour is true, if unfortunate. Marking as WONTFIX.
creator: conor@apache.org
